data.title: Musto Gunning For Brace In Race; Pizzella Runs Super Bowl Ads Ray Musto Just Never Forgets.
data.meta_description: Sunday, January 26, 1997     Page: Musto gunning for Brace in race; Pizzella runs Super Bowl ads     Ray Musto just never forgetsWhile he says he’s “not going to get into that county controller fight,” Musto doesn’t hesitate to tell anybody who’ll listen that the one guy he’ll do what he can to knock out of […]
data.text:
Sunday, January 26, 1997 Page:

Musto gunning for Brace in race; Pizzella runs Super Bowl ads

Ray Musto just never forgetsWhile he says he’s “not going to get into that

county controller fight,” Musto doesn’t hesitate to tell anybody who’ll listen

that the one guy he’ll do what he can to knock out of the box is Bill Brace.

Musto has been carrying a grudge in his craw against Brace going back to

when Brace backed Mike Conahan, when Conahan and Joe Musto battled for the

county judgeship that Conahan won.

Musto’s also still ticked that Brace was for Neil O’Donnell against him in

that state Senate nominating primary a few years ago that also included Frank

Trinisewski.

Musto beat O’Donnell and Trinisewski, of course, and went on to win another

state Senate term, which he’s serving in now.

Brace, who is Wilkes-Barre City Clerk, is in the field of Democratic

candidates for county controller in the May 20 primary. The others are Frank

Pizzella of Plains and, supposedly, Tom Pisano of Exeter.

Musto doesn’t have much to say about Pizzella and Pisano, but mention Brace

and he boils over.

“Brace has a lot of nerve asking for the Democratic Executive Committee’s

endorsement,” Musto says.

“When I was the Executive Committee’s endorsed candidate for the state

Senate in the primary of 1994,” Musto says, “Brace went out and tried to knock

my head off.”

Brace, Musto practically rages, “has never done anything for the Democratic

Party in all the years he’s been a Democrat, if that’s what he really is, and

he’s selfish and has never been a team player.”

Musto says Brace “will have trouble in the city” and from him as well.

“I’m against Brace and he’s going to find that out on election day,” Musto

says.

Brace supposedly went to county Democratic Chairman Jimmy Bach and asked

him for the Democratic endorsement for controller, something Brace denies, but

Bach turned him down. Bach says there aren’t going to be any endorsements

until some time in May. Musto didn’t like it one bit that Brace supposedly

went to Bach for the endorsement.

When he was told that Musto was out to chop him up, Brace said, “I know

he’s mad at me because I backed Mike Conahan in the city in that judgeship

primary election, but I can’t worry about that because I have a campaign to

run.”

Brace says he was for Conahan because they have been personal friends going

back years and years, and as far as supporting O’Donnell, Brace says “Neil is

a friend of mine, too.”

All of that, Brace says, is in the past. “Past elections are past,” he

says. “And, besides, I have nothing personal against Sen. Musto; in fact, I

respect him and I think he’s doing a good job in Harrisburg.”

Brace says his campaign is doing very well.

“I have fund-raisers scheduled for all around the county; I’ll have $100 a

ticket get-together on Jan. 31, that’s this coming Friday, at the Ramada and

then I’ll have others in Hazleton and Pittston and elsewhere,” he says.

Moneybags Pizzella

Frank Pizzella is telling everybody that he has bought up tons of

advertising — television, radio, buses, billboards and so on — in his

campaign to grab the Democratic nomination for county controller.

In fact, they were saying Pizzella has two ads on Fox 38’s broadcast of the

Super Bowl today.

To advertise like that, you really need serious money.

Pizzella, a Plains Township commissioner, claims he’s “loaded with cash”

and won’t hesitate to turn it loose to win in the May 20 primary.

Money is the mother’s milk of politics, so they say.

Yencha not being turned

If you saw that ad in both newspapers on January 20 congratulating Greg

Skrepenak, Rocket Ismail and Bucky Greeley for helping the Carolina Panthers

to a winning season, you might be wondering why Republican John Yencha’s name

was included in it along with the names of Democrats Alice Corba, Sally

Jervis, Mike Rushton.

The way the ad was presented anybody reading it naturally would conclude

that here are the four incumbent Wilkes-Barre School Board candidates in this

year’s elections running as a “team.”

But that’s really not the case.

According to Yencha, he got a brief look at the original copy of the ad,

which was signed “Paid for by Committee to Reelect Corba, Jervis, Rushton,

Yencha,” and didn’t object to it being printed in the newspapers. To him, it

seemed like a nice tribute toward those three star football players.

And even though it looked very much like he was part of a

Corba-Jervis-Rushton “team,” that’s not the way it is.

“I’m still on my own,” Yencha says.

Even though Yencha keeps saying that, Rushton still thinks he can turn him

to Democrat so they’ll have an all-Democratic team for the School Board

elections.

Good luck, Mike. Just don’t hold your breath on that one.

Burns picks campaign chief

Democratic prothonotary candidate Jim Burns has picked Bob Savakinus of

Hudson, an active member of the Young Democrats, as his campaign director.

Burns, saying he “senses change in the air,” is challenging incumbent

Democratic prothonotary Gene Duffy for the Democratic nomination on May 20.

This is Burns’s third crack at a county row office nomination. He

previously ran for county controller against the late Joe Tirpak, and for

recorder of deeds against the incumbent Frank Castellino. Burns lost both

times.

Joey “I” aims at Toole

It looks like Michael Lombardo, son of Dr. Joseph Lombardo, is going to

challenge incumbent Pittston Mayor Tom Walsh for the Democratic nomination for

mayor in the May 20 primary.

Word out of Pittston is that Joey Infantino is putting together a ticket to

try to take out Walsh and incumbent Democratic Councilmen John Argo and Jim

Kolmansberger.

Lombardo would head the Infantino slate, which also would include

Infantino’s son Charlie. The second council candidate on this slate hasn’t

been chosen just yet.

Infantino — they call him Joey “I” — would like to call the shots at City

Hall so he can get rid of his arch enemy, City Clerk Wil Toole.

Knowing he’ll be out if Walsh and the incumbent councilmen lose, Toole has

been shopping for a county job, which he’s not likely to ever get because

Infantino is close with Tom Makowski and is sure to keep Toole blocked out as

long as he can.

Toole is said to have tried to smooth things over with Joey “I”, but never

got to first base.

By the way, Mayor Tom Walsh is a wonderful guy.

The way it was

Just to set things straight for the guys on the Wilkes-Barre City Council.

Mike McGinley did not — repeat: did not — “run to the newspaper” with the

story about him and you other guys on the council that was in this space last

Sunday.

The sources for that story, and the story about Tommy McGroarty and

McGinley as well, weren’t McGinley or anybody in the McGinley family.

Both of those stories came out of connections other than the McGinleys.

Just wanted to clear that up.

Columnist Bill Griffith’s notes on county and city politics appear on

Sunday.
